text:
Hi everyone, I'm currently trying to transition from content writing to content marketing but I'm not sure how to put together a content marketing portfolio so I can start applying for jobs. Any tips or advice?

P.S: I was recently hired as a Marketing and Communications Lead at an early-stage startup with zero experience. I'm settling in nicely on the job and doing a lot of learning. Not sure if this info is relevant but I just thought to add it. Would be in the replies for your tips and guidance. Thanks!

elements.text:

Not sure if this info is relevant but I just thought to add it. Would be in the replies for your tips and guidance. Thanks!

text: I've been freelance for over 10 years now. A couple of years ago I was offered a full-time senior role at a large digital agency - I considered it for a couple of weeks then accepted the role as I thought I was ready for a change. I was then laid off after 8 months when their client work dipped. I was able to pick up freelance work again straightaway and have not looked back since. I love being freelance and couldn't imagine working for someone else again. I have kids and as a rule I never work weekends and rarely ever evenings. Set your own boundaries.

text:
In my opinion, the best route you can take is to find clients who will provide you with flexible working hours and a long-term commitment.

I honestly think it is better to settle for a writing agency that will constantly provide work. Depending on whether you want to work on different topics or write content for one brand, it can also be a client.

An excellent example of this is a shopping retailer where you write their articles, product descriptions, and all of the content on their website in general.

elements.text:
In my opinion, the best route you can take is to find clients who will provide you with flexible working hours and a long-term commitment.

I honestly think it is better to settle for a writing agency that will constantly provide work. Depending on whether you want to work on different topics or write content for one brand, it can also be a client.

An excellent example of this is a shopping retailer where you write their articles, product descriptions, and all of the content on their website in general.

text:
Since content marketing is more sales-oriented, a good portfolio would show examples of your results. Here you would list the amount of money you brought to the company in sales using your content marketing skills.

If you don't have a lot of experience doing that, maybe a good way to start is pitching content marketing plans and ideas to your manager in your current content writing job?

Once you generate some leads or sales, you can put them into your portfolio.

elements.text:

text: To piggyback off of <@U02CVNB3X1T>'s question about switching from freelance to full time...anyone have any interview tips to make a freelance candidate more desirable for a regular position? Could be from the candidate side and/or the hiring side. If there's another channel I should ask this in, let me know.

text: I just sent over a project rate for a client who is having me edit/fix 6 articles that were actual garbage. (i'm still shocked people use "thus" in articles). Anyhow, since I have to actually rewrite a lot of the content and add in additional SEO work, I charged them $1000 for 6..which I thought was high...which is, in all reality, pretty low. ha!

text: This is a great question, and as someone who has been in and out of "maybe I will apply" and "maybe I won't" I've pulled together a specific resume/cover letter that is for full time jobs. If the job is about strategy, Ill put together a deck on strategy. Content writing gig? Ill put together a deck with content I've written. I think my work will make me more desirable...the problem is that I always bail before I apply for full time. I have that wishy-washy panic about full time...even though I'm on the freelancer fence.

text: The prospect has a ~5000-word multi-part guide that he needs help editing, which includes re-writing ~1000 words. I'm used to doing value-based pricing or monthly retainers with strategy/content clients; that doesn't really work here, lol. Any ideas on a reasonable rate?

text:
In almost 2 years of content writing, I have never seen so many projects change direction or get completely changed before. I am trying to remain professional and give them the benefit of the doubt while not giving up yet since I am trying to look at this as a learning experience for myself. However, they hired me to write for their blog with no real existing content plan in place at all and I am about to the stress level of questioning my writing expertise altogether.

Does anyone have any real advice/tips on clients who continuously pivot project scopes, ask for multiple revisions, and basically micromanage the project without driving myself insane?
Please share! Thanks!

elements.text:

However, they hired me to write for their blog with no real existing content plan in place at all and I am about to the stress level of questioning my writing expertise altogether.

Does anyone have any real advice/tips on clients who continuously pivot project scopes, ask for multiple revisions, and basically micromanage the project without driving myself insane?
Please share! Thanks!

text:

This year I’m working on positioning myself for a leadership role while still growing as a content strategist. 
Currently exploring different courses and certifications. Also considering going back to school to for communications. What would you all suggest/recommend?

text: This is kind of a self-serving answer... but addressing this problem is one of the big goals of <https://www.thewritingcompany.com/|the agency> where I'm a partner. We're an editorial agency that cultivates close relationships with our writers, most of whom are freelance. We work really hard to develop a teaching/learning community, to give writers and editors an array of types of work and - not for nothing - to pay fast.  My days include a lot of collaboration with our team, and I really value that a lot.

attachments.fallback: The Writing Company: The Writing Company | Smart writing on complex topics
attachments.text: We write about finance, health care, tech, business, lifestyle and more. Our team creates the copy you need to help your audience navigate a complex world.
attachments.title: The Writing Company | Smart writing on complex topics

text:
I struggled with this at my current company. Then I started setting boundaries. 
• All content requests must be submitted via a form that has questions where I ask about the goals/scope of the project. 
• We have a call where we confirm said goals for  the project. I express there will only be 2 no more than 3 opportunities to revise the goals/scope of the project on the call and ask clarify questions and set expectations. 
I think you should clear the air by getting in agreement about what the goal is for the piece you are writing and then express to them any changes from that point on will include a fee (paid upfront). Or fire them as clients. It goes both ways. Hope this helps! Wishing you all the best. I know how frustrating it can be.

elements.text: I struggled with this at my current company. Then I started setting boundaries.

We have a call where we confirm said goals for  the project. I express there will only be 2 no more than 3 opportunities to revise the goals/scope of the project on the call and ask clarify questions and set expectations.

I think you should clear the air by getting in agreement about what the goal is for the piece you are writing and then express to them any changes from that point on will include a fee (paid upfront). Or fire them as clients. It goes both ways. Hope this helps! Wishing you all the best. I know how frustrating it can be.

text:
Make sure when they sign the contract that they understand there's "additional fees for changes beyond the existing scope that will be billed ahead of the work at $X/hr."

Use almost that exact language. It gets your paid ahead of the work for any changes. Then, rigidly adhere to the scope.

elements.text:
Make sure when they sign the contract that they understand there's "additional fees for changes beyond the existing scope that will be billed ahead of the work at $X/hr."

Use almost that exact language. It gets your paid ahead of the work for any changes. Then, rigidly adhere to the scope.

text: I would never (ever) use market rate or inflation or anything like that in negotiation. 100% focus on you, your skillset, your experience, and your history driving value for clients.

elements.text: I would never (ever) use market rate or inflation or anything like that in negotiation. 100% focus on you, your skillset, your experience, and your history driving value for clients.

text: Also, that sounded curt (don't mean it to), but having negotiated salary with people I've managed probably 50+ times, that's always been my direct feedback for them. If they want more money, help me understand how they'll have an outsized financial impact where it makes it a no-brainer to fight my bosses to give them that.

elements.text: Also, that sounded curt (don't mean it to), but having negotiated salary with people I've managed probably 50+ times, that's always been my direct feedback for them. If they want more money, help me understand how they'll have an outsized financial impact where it makes it a no-brainer to fight my bosses to give them that.

text:
Hi Tobi! I'm a content editor for a marketing agency. We work with a ton of different clients and writers to develop branded content. My number one request from clients is for their style guide—clients without a style guide generally raise a tiny red flag for me. When briefing writers who are hopping on the account, they are always instructed to review brand guidelines. I think as content creators we are tasked to be chameleons. If we are being hired by clients who haven't invested in their brand ... it creates issues all across the board. I think the advice above is great. Having examples of work that the client feels aligned with is an ideal first step into creating content that feels authentic.

If they are a client that you would like to invest in an ongoing relationship with, I suggest mentioning how beneficial a set of brand guidelines are for content creators. Sometimes this is an avenue for additional work for you or folks in your network. Happy to chat further if you'd like!

text: I freelanced for about 7 years and just went back to a full-time job in December 2021. I agree with everything <@U02D1E37FL5> said, I’m not tired all the time, and I love having my weekends back! The stability has been wonderful. It’s still early days, but for where I was mentally with freelancing, this was the right decision.
